data.title: JSON schema resolution does not work with $ref in definitions
Typing a parenthese triggers autocomplete
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version:  Windows 10 Pro N 1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type a function name
![vscode-autocomplete](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5290053/26891547-11177db2-4bbe-11e7-9ebb-5fbad92b7777.PNG)
2. Type a parenthese `(`
3. VSCode autocompletes the fuction against my will
![vscode-autocomplete2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5290053/26891571-2494bed6-4bbe-11e7-860a-dd4e7b1cf736.PNG)

Related settings:
```
"editor.acceptSuggestionOnEnter": false,
"editor.autoClosingBrackets": false,
"editor.formatOnType": false,
```

Seems impossible to turn off this super annoying feature. Autocomplete should only trigger when pressing tab if I've set up the settings correctly.

data.title: Environment variables from launch.json need escaping when "console" is set to either "integratedTerminal" or "externalTerminal"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10, OSX Sierra (tested both) 

We use launch.json `env` block for configuration of software (think `nconf` or similar). We found this by a number of things: 

 - For the inspector debug protocol, `process.stdout.write` does not get echod to the debug console, so we switched to integratedTerminal. 
 - We have some config we set that are endpoints, some of these endpoints have url query params in them, thus the `&`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `bash` as your integrated shell
2. Add the following env to your launch.json for a `node` type project

```json
"env": {
    "foo": "bar&bar",
    "foo2": "hello"
}
```

3. Debug (`F5`) the project 

Expected:
`process.env.foo === "bar&bar" && process.env.foo2 === "hello"`

Actual: 
No environment variables from launch.json (process.env) are set. 

Diagnosis:
VSCode needs to escape (quote?) the values when starting a debug target within the context of a terminal (integrated or external). When the environment variables are set, vscode does something like this on launch: 

```bash
foo=bar&bar
foo2=hello
``` 

It should be something like

```bash
foo="bar&bar"
foo2="hello"
``` 

Otherwise the `&` is interpreted as a fork operator (for `bash` at-least). This would enable someone to do something like:

```json
"env": { 
     "foo": "bar&echo hello world" 
}
```

data.title: What's the correct way to asynchronously handle a debugger disconnectRequest?
data.body:
I'm trying to handle the disconnectRequest in my debug adapter. I'm talking to a service over STDIO and want to allow it to gracefully shutdown. I've overridden `disconnectRequest` and send my shutdown request to my service from there, but I do _not_ call `super.disconnectRequest`. However, no matter how I then try to end the debug session later (eg. sending a `TerminatedEvent`) the debug toolbar doesn't disappear from Code unless I click the Stop button for a second time.

So what's the correct way to handle a disconnectRequest asynchronously, and signal to Code the session has finished "later"?

This displays as incorrect, but it's valid.

data.title: Column Selection by Middle Mouse Button (Sublime Style)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro 64-bit

Currently column select is available by pressing `Alt + Shift + Mouse Left` to drag colum selection from current cursor position. Or by `Alt + Ctrl + Shift + Arrows` without the mouse. 

Nice feature, but horrible to use.
I think it would be better if the behaviour is the same like in sublime text or atom package: 
https://atom.io/packages/Sublime-Style-Column-Selection

Just press the middle mouse button (mouse wheel) to select from every position. 
The middle click also sets the start position (cursor) dynamically. 
Optional set other keys for example `Alt + Mouse Left`.

Look this clip: (Only controlled by the mouse middle button with the package (link above) in Atom.)
![columnselect](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28209992/26884862-174f2562-4ba1-11e7-8da7-c0f56baeea4b.gif)

data.title: Snippet order for placeholders
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13-0-Insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1607 (OS Build 14393.1198)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a snippet with the following placeholders: ${10:Foo} ${2:Baz}

**Expected:** Starts the snippet at 2:Baz since it is the lowest number, Press Tab and it moves to 10:Foo
**Actual:** Start the snippet at 10:Foo Press Tab and it moves to 2:Baz

The documentation for snippet placeholders: 
placeholder ::= '${' int ':' any '}'
So I expect the value before the colon to be treated as an integer not as text.

data.title: Cursor Colour
data.body:
It would be great if I could change the colour of the cursor in settings.json.

All my other programs allow me to do this but in vscode I have trouble telling which pane is active when having 2 editors and a terminal displayed because all the cursors are the same colour. 

Being able to set the active cursor colour would help alleviate the other UX issues regarding active panel by drawing attention to the active cursor. 

I can add screen shots of what other editors and terminals do if that helps. 

Otherwise loving VS Code :)

data.title: "editor.formatOnPaste": should not be true by default
data.body:
The setting 'editor.formatOnPaste' got changed to true.

I don't think this is a good idea. It will cause a lot of issues.

The problem is that the feature builds on format ranges. I've tried to get the HTML formatter to correctly format ranges, but it's a very hard problem as the underlying formatter (jsbeatify) is designed to only format full documents.
Using it only a subrange doesn't work. Giving it the full content and trying to remove changes outside the range doesn't work, as the changes inside the range are depending on the changes outside (e.g. for indent).
I've come up with some heuristics, but I'm aware that there are many corner cases that will result in strangeness.
While I think that's acceptable for a 'format range' comment, where the user picks a range (mostly while lines), and can easily undo, this is too risky to be applied on every paste, by default.
Even in the cases where it kind of works, it is irritating (see #28084).

I strongly recommend setting the default of editor.formatOnPaste to `false` again. It can be turned on selectively for languages where we know the underlying formatter plays well enough with it.

data.title: Problem matchers referenced in API will not be resolved correctly
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: master
- OS Version: Windows

Steps:

- workspace with tsconfig.json
- have problems in workspace
- execute contributed tasks

Observe: errors don't show up in error list

The reason is that the problem matcher names is referenced $tsc and not tsc. We should support for compatibility reasons $tsc as well.

data.title: Every morning, closing vscode locks up my machine
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 7
- TF.exe Version: 14.102.25619.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Leave VS Code running overnight
2. Close VS Code

I know this sounds odd, what with vs code being a user process and everything but every morning I can click around in vs code but when I close the window vs code freezes and then so does explorer (the task bar etc) and then the mouse stops moving.

Ctrl+Alt+Del do nothing, neither does Ctrl+Shift+Esc 

I added the ctrl+scroll lock+scroll lock to crash the machine and that still works, I get a kernel dump.

In the dump it shows that there is one lock and all the other processes start waiting on that lock:

`
0: kd> !locks
**** DUMP OF ALL RESOURCE OBJECTS ****
KD: Scanning for held locks...........................

Resource @ 0xfffffa801009b9b0    Exclusively owned
    Contention Count = 113827279
    NumberOfSharedWaiters = 2
    NumberOfExclusiveWaiters = 65
     Threads: fffffa8010a61b50-01<*> fffffa801a797720-01    fffffa8018f4fb50-01

     Threads Waiting On Exclusive Access:
              fffffa801d297940       fffffa801950eb50       fffffa80154cbb50       fffffa80142979e0
              fffffa8011e2e060       fffffa8015f47b50       fffffa8015a2eb50       fffffa80143ecb50
              fffffa801c8ba060       fffffa801a4ea5f0       fffffa80196a0060       fffffa8014598060
              fffffa8015d61a00       fffffa800da64060       fffffa8015194060       fffffa80153e2060
              fffffa80182da7f0       fffffa8011f23810       fffffa8015c95060       fffffa801238fb50
              fffffa80164d7060       fffffa801ddb5060       fffffa80156ed6f0       fffffa801972db50
              fffffa8011eeab50       fffffa801b539b50       fffffa8013f99710       fffffa800d47db50
              fffffa8015b24450       fffffa80162d6b50       fffffa800dcec060       fffffa8015433710
              fffffa8011edb060       fffffa8018c0e060       fffffa8014013b50       fffffa801403e610
              fffffa801402c060       fffffa8015f3d060       fffffa801405c060       fffffa801409b710
              fffffa80150ac060       fffffa8013fed060       fffffa8014334060       fffffa800d4f66b0
              fffffa80187c4b50       fffffa8010bee5c0       fffffa8011f2d830       fffffa801569fb50
              fffffa8018d39840       fffffa80187a0540       fffffa80161ccb50       fffffa801bfefb50
              fffffa8016e99b50       fffffa8019ac0b50       fffffa801637b060       fffffa8015d246a0
              fffffa8019430b50       fffffa80156c7320       fffffa8016a5c060       fffffa8018909200
              fffffa800dc06b50       fffffa8016fa96f0       fffffa80160ff5c0       fffffa8016207060
              fffffa8016d82060
KD: Scanning for held locks........................................................................
59188 total locks, 1 locks currently held
`

The lock is owned tf.exe:
`
0: kd> !thread fffffa8010a61b50
THREAD fffffa8010a61b50  Cid 3648.292c  Teb: 00000000fffdb000 Win32Thread: fffff900c2acab90 RUNNING on processor 1
Not impersonating
DeviceMap                 fffff8a0042244e0
Owning Process            fffffa801861ab10       Image:         TF.exe
Attached Process          N/A            Image:         N/A
Wait Start TickCount      5527054        Ticks: 0
Context Switch Count      7309           IdealProcessor: 1                 LargeStack
UserTime                  00:00:00.078
KernelTime                00:00:16.692
Win32 Start Address 0x000000000136bec2
Stack Init fffff8800e949c70 Current fffff8800e949260
`

It happens every morning and this lock is always owned by tf.exe :(



Any ideas?

data.title: Space before block comment
data.body:
When toggling block comment, it should be `/* comment */` rather than `/*comment*/`,
just like it's `// comment` rather than `//comment` in line comment.

data.title: Javascript bitwise operators in for loop declaration break syntax highlight.
data.body:
Hello I'm thinking to start using VS Code as my new code editor and was checking how it's handle syntax highlight.

And i found this bug.

![screen1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1374690/26866466-e31a816a-4b69-11e7-91ec-513a3f7478a4.jpg)

Incorrect highlight for comments, "var", "function", "for" declaration
Basically most of the highlight below line #12 is broken

If I change len to a number then all is fine

![screen2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1374690/26866472-e978a488-4b69-11e7-8f61-b2962a355961.jpg)

Or I can wrap bitwise expression in brackets and then syntax highlight return to normal too.

![screen3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1374690/26866480-f25c06d0-4b69-11e7-866f-53e4f3fd68d2.jpg)

Probably its a rare example of bitwise operators usage in real life but still..

data.title: Code lens no longer seem to be sorted by their range
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.13.0-insider (c8123b036b66ca6e319bae00bfd7c34bb1ad977b, 2017-06-06T21:31:11.642Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16199
---

Maybe I'm imagining it (or maybe it was only for code lens from the same provider), but I thought code lens where show in order based on their range.

I quickly hacked vscode to display the range at the end of the code lens -- and you can see here that the implementation and references code lens have a cols that are before the GitLens ones.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/641685/26865320-20d87b64-4b2a-11e7-8eba-2bde8bc802f8.png)

In the latest (beta) of GitLens I was trying to force my code lens to always be at the end of the line (because I would MUCH rather have implementations and references at the start), but even with adding the code lens range at the end of the line, it doesn't seem to help the ordering. I'm really hoping to be able to provide at least some level of consistency to the positioning of the code lens if at all possible.

Did this change? Is there any way to get this behavior?

//cc @jrieken
